Birds and Rocks

A highly versatile and prolific artist from Maoming (present-day Gaozhou) in Guangdong province, Ting Yin-yung was celebrated for his traditional ink paintings and seal carvings, as well as his works as an oil painter. He studied Western painting at the Tokyo School of Fine Arts in Japan between 1920 and 1925, before working in Shanghai, Guangzhou and Chongqing. While employed at the Guangzhou Museum in 1929, he was exposed to many historical paintings and artists, which cultivated his interest in traditional Chinese painting. 
He was a great admirer of Bada Shamen (1626-1705), a painter and calligrapher celebrated for his enigmatic images of birds and fish imbued with human characteristics. When Ting Hei Guangdong for Hong Kong at the end of the Chinese Communist Revolution in 1949, he brought with him several paintings by Bada Shamen, which he studied extensively, publishing a detailed account of his collection of Bada's work and significance to modern art in 1961. "The bird in the painting stands arrogantly on a rock, reflecting Bada Shamen's style and spirit."
